dt: {bc}the power or process of reproducing or recalling what has been learned and retained especially through associative mechanisms

dt.t: began to lose his {wi}memory{/wi} as he grew older

dt: {bc}the store of things learned and retained from an organism's activity or experience as evidenced by modification of structure or behavior or by recall and recognition

dt.t: erected a statue in {wi}memory{/wi} of the hero

dt: {bc}the fact or condition of being remembered
{bc}a particular act of recall or recollection
{bc}an image or impression of one that is remembered
{bc}the time within which past events can be or are remembered
{bc}a device (such as a chip) or a component of an electronic device (such as a computer or smartphone) in which information can be inserted and stored and from which it may be extracted when wanted
{bc}a capacity for showing effects as the result of past treatment or for returning to a former condition
used especially of a material (such as metal or plastic)

pt: {sc}memory{/sc} {sc}remembrance{/sc} {sc}recollection{/sc} {sc}reminiscence{/sc} mean the capacity for or the act of remembering, or the thing remembered. {sc}memory{/sc} applies both to the power of remembering and to what is remembered.

pt.t: that incident was now just a distant {it}memory{/it}

pt: {sc}remembrance{/sc} applies to the act of remembering or the fact of being remembered.

pt.t: any {it}remembrance{/it} of his deceased wife was painful

pt: {sc}recollection{/sc} adds an implication of consciously bringing back to mind often with some effort.

pt.t: after a moment's {it}recollection{/it} he produced the name

pt: {sc}reminiscence{/sc} suggests the recalling of usually pleasant incidents, experiences, or feelings from a remote past.

pt.t: my grandmother's {it}reminiscences{/it} of her Iowa girlhood

et: Middle English {it}memorie{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}memoire, memorie{/it}, from Latin {it}memoria{/it}, from {it}memor{/it} mindful; akin to Old English {it}gemimor{/it} well-known, Greek {it}mermēra{/it} care, Sanskrit {it}smarati{/it} he remembers
shortdef: the power or process of reproducing or recalling what has been learned and retained especially through associative mechanisms
the store of things learned and retained from an organism's activity or experience as evidenced by modification of structure or behavior or by recall and recognition

dt: {bc}a computer memory that uses {d_link|magnetic bubbles|magnetic bubble} to store information

shortdef: a computer memory that uses magnetic bubbles to store information

dt: {bc}the uncommon ability that allows a person to spontaneously recall with great accuracy and detail a vast number of personal events or experiences and their associated dates {bc}{sx|hyperthymesia||}

dt.t: {wi}Highly superior autobiographical memory{/wi} allows one to recall the day, date and year of any major celebrity death they took note of, to remember what they had for dinner and how the weather was on any given day of any month and year, and to list off the matchups of their favorite sports teams like anyone else could only do by reading off of Wikipedia.

People with an extremely rare condition called {ldquo}{wi}highly superior autobiographical memory{/wi}{rdquo} have the ability to remember every single event in their lives from a certain date in their childhood onward. If you ask them about an event they can remember the exact date, the weather and what they ate for lunch that day—and they can visualize it as vividly as if it happened yesterday.

shortdef: the uncommon ability that allows a person to spontaneously recall with great accuracy and detail a vast number of personal events or experiences and their associated dates : hyperthymesia

dt: {bc}a memory of a traumatic event (such as sexual abuse) experienced typically during childhood that is forgotten and then recalled many years later that is sometimes held to be an invalid or false remembrance generated by outside influence

shortdef: a memory of a traumatic event (such as sexual abuse) experienced typically during childhood that is forgotten and then recalled many years later that is sometimes held to be an invalid or false remembrance generated by outside influence

dt: {bc}a recollection of early childhood that may be falsely recalled or magnified in importance and that masks another memory of deep emotional significance

shortdef: a recollection of early childhood that may be falsely recalled or magnified in importance and that masks another memory of deep emotional significance

dt: {bc}a section of a hard drive that can be used as if it were an extension of a computer's random-access memory

shortdef: a section of a hard drive that can be used as if it were an extension of a computer's random-access memory —called also virtual storage
